Award.AwardTitle: Recombination, Genetic Interactions, and Observable Evolutionary Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to develop quantitative understanding of the evolutionary dynamics of large populations with abundant selection and recombination by analyzing a variety of models that build in various of the key features. The interplay between multiple beneficial mutations accumulating in one lineage and recombination that breaks apart and brings together collections of such mutations will be studied in several situations: re-assortment, the exchange of chromosomes between individuals without recombination as occurs for influenza viruses; transfer of small segments of a genome as in lateral gene transfer between bacteria; occasional mating between otherwise asexually evolving populations, as in yeast; and various approximations of the spectrum of degrees of linkage that arise from the linear structure of chromosomes. Epistatic interactions between mutations together with changing linkage leads to a balance between selection on individual genes and selection on genomes: this will be explored for various models of the interactions focusing on the statistical properties of the rare, anomalously good combinations of mutations that dominate the future evolution. The models of epistasis will be informed by, and inform, experiments on laboratory evolution of budding yeast carried out by collaborators. Mating within or between asexually evolved populations that have been "barcoded", should provide crucial information about the fitness of parents and their offspring, and the theory developed will enable predictions about the benefits of sex that can be tested in future experiments. Going beyond well-mixed populations in which all individuals compete directly, other forms of competition that could be realized in the laboratory (such as selection of the best half of a population) will be studied. Spatial structure and the interplay between local competition and mixing on longer time scales will also be investigated, focusing on the effects of recombination on rates of evolution and dynamics of diversity. Collaborations with several groups carrying out laboratory evolution experiments with yeast or bacteria will be further developed to obtain statistical information needed for the modeling, and to propose and plan future experiments. Analysis of deep sequencing data of bacterial populations will be carried out with collaborators to infer aspects of the evolutionary history, including recombination, and to develop plans for the most informative future sampling and sequencing. The students and postdocs involved will greatly benefit from mentoring by several faculty from different fields. Beyond the research, the PI is developing new courses on evolution for quantitative scientists and biologists: lecture notes will be made available on the internet. The PI will also become further involved in educating the general public about evolution, including the future challenges, as well as the successes, of evolutionary theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The DNA sequencing revolution has, for the first time, enabled following the dynamics of evolution as it occurs.  But to develop new understanding of the fundamental processes and to make sense of and effectively use such huge quantities of data, a close interplay between abstract theory and modeling, laboratory experiments, and observations of natural populations, is essential. This project has taken up these challenges on a spectrum of fronts, with a variety of collaborators. 

Large populations of bacteria, viruses, and cancers behave strikingly differently than the conventional picture of slow evolution: many beneficial mutations arise, compete, and accumulate giving rise to continual evolution. The now-measurable statistics of the genetic diversity in large asexual populations reflect clearly the theoretical predictions of this complex  process.   Tracking the early stages of such evolution in the laboratory was made possible by developments from a collaboration to label individual yeast cells with DNA barcodes and track the their descendants. The spectrum of tens of thousands of beneficial mutations, how they are beneficial, and their sensitivity to conditions have been studied leading to insights into the complexities of evolution even in the simplest conditions.
This has helped motivate abstract modeling of complex “fitness landscapes”, evolution in them, and how they are affected by the evolution. The large number of “dimensions” of the organismic and environmental properties give rise to simplifications and generalizations. A striking prediction is   the ubiquity of “Red Queen” evolution in which even slight modifications of their environments by an evolving population can make it evolve forever without slowing down - it has to run fast just to stay in place.

Within individual humans, the immune system works by evolving antibodies that better recognize pathogens. DNA sequencing of “repertoires” of antibodies in individual people has led to tracking of their response to influenza vaccines.  An unexpected and puzzling result is the lack of overlap in the antibodies produced by different people but much redundancy in those produced within each person.

Between humans, new strains of pathogens can spread rapidly — an example of a general process of spread of fitter variants of a species. New theory shows how occasional long-distance transport — frequent over short distances and becoming progressively rarer over longer distances — dramatically speeds up the spread. For influenza,  this is driven by global air travel but the theory also gives new insights on spread of other diseases, such as mosquito carried dengue within cities, as well as plankton moved by ocean currents.   

Sexual evolution is much more complex than asexual evolution.  Particularly difficult to understand is the role of very infrequent genetic exchange which is characteristic of bacteria.   Analysis of a simple model shows that the larger a population is, the lower the rate of genetic exchange is needed to substantially speed up the evolution. Understanding the diversity and patterns in genomes that this gives rise to is a major challenge. For an environmental population of a single species, cyanobacteria from Yellowstone hot springs,  in depth analysis shows evidence for extensive diversity within a single small sample and imprints of a history of genetic exchange and mixing between the springs. Various aspects  appear  consistent with conventional scenarios for evolution and diversity, but the evidence as a whole points to far more complex ecological and evolutionary forces.  This is an example of how coupling theory and development of new statistical analyses can motivate and distinguish between scenarios leading to insights far beyond most “big data” approaches.    

Most of the students and postdocs trained under this grant came from  theoretical physics with no biology backgrounds and developed into top notch researchers with a broad and cutting edge base of expertise in population genetics, data analysis, theoretical modeling, and, most crucially, the ability to frame new questions that move well beyond current paradigms. Two who have finished their training have gone into research positions at biotech companies and the third to a group leader position at a cancer center: his research supported by this grant enabled a rapid transition to innovative research at the forefront of evolutionary dynamics of cancers.   

The PI has given talks on evolution for general audiences and many to physics departments interested in broadening out into areas in which physicists can frame and address new biological questions.
